text: Which king issued the decree allowing the Jews to return to Jerusalem and rebuild the Temple?
verseText: In the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, that the word of the LORD by the mouth of Jeremiah might be fulfilled, the LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia, so that he made a proclamation throughout all his kingdom and also put it in writing: 'Thus says Cyrus king of Persia: The LORD, the God of heaven, has given me all the kingdoms of the earth, and he has charged me to build him a house at Jerusalem, which is in Judah.' (ESV)

text: Who led the first group of exiles back to Judah?
verseText: They came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Seraiah, Reelaiah, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispar, Bigvai, Rehum, Baanah. The number of the men of the people of Israel: (ESV)

text: What was the primary task the first returning exiles set out to accomplish?
verseText: Whoever is among you of all his people, may his God be with him, and let him go up to Jerusalem, which is in Judah, and rebuild the house of the LORD, the God of Israelâ€”he is the God who is in Jerusalem. (ESV)

text: What was the first structure the returning exiles rebuilt?
verseText: Then arose Jeshua the son of Jozadak, with his fellow priests, and Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel with his kinsmen, and they built the altar of the God of Israel, to offer burnt offerings on it, as it is written in the Law of Moses the man of God. (ESV)

text: What happened when the foundation of the second Temple was laid?
options: Some people shouted for joy, while older people wept
verseText: And they sang responsively, praising and giving thanks to the LORD... But many of the priests and Levites and heads of fathers' houses, old men who had seen the first house, wept with a loud voice when they saw the foundation of this house being laid, though many shouted aloud for joy... (ESV)

text: Who opposed the rebuilding of the Temple in the early stages?
options: The adversaries of Judah and Benjamin (Samaritans)
verseText: Now when the adversaries of Judah and Benjamin heard that the returned exiles were building a temple to the LORD, the God of Israel, they approached Zerubbabel and the heads of fathers' houses and said to them, 'Let us build with you, for we worship your God as you do...' (ESV)

text: Which two prophets encouraged the people to resume rebuilding the Temple after work had stopped?
verseText: Now the prophets, Haggai and Zechariah the son of Iddo, prophesied to the Jews who were in Judah and Jerusalem, in the name of the God of Israel who was over them. (ESV)

text: Which Persian king reaffirmed Cyrus's decree and ordered the Temple rebuilding to continue with state funding?
verseText: Then Darius the king made a decree, and search was made in Babylonia, in the house of the archives where the documents were stored... Moreover, I make a decree regarding what you shall do for these elders of the Jews for the rebuilding of this house of God. The cost is to be paid to these men in full and without delay from the royal revenue... (ESV)

text: In which year of King Darius's reign was the second Temple completed?
verseText: And this house was finished on the third day of the month of Adar, in the sixth year of the reign of Darius the king. (ESV)

text: What festival did the Israelites celebrate after completing and dedicating the Temple?
verseText: On the fourteenth day of the first month, the returned exiles kept the Passover... And they kept the Feast of Unleavened Bread seven days with joy, for the LORD had made them joyful and had turned the heart of the king of Assyria to them, so that he aided them in the work of the house of God, the God of Israel. (ESV)

text: Who was Ezra?
options: A scribe skilled in the Law of Moses
verseText: this Ezra went up from Babylonia. He was a scribe skilled in the Law of Moses that the LORD, the God of Israel, had given... (ESV)

text: Which Persian king commissioned Ezra to go to Jerusalem?
verseText: Now after this, in the reign of Artaxerxes king of Persia, Ezra the son of Seraiah... This is a copy of the letter that King Artaxerxes gave to Ezra the priest, the scribe... (ESV)

text: What was Ezra's main purpose in returning to Jerusalem?
options: To teach the Law of God and restore proper worship
To lead a rebellion against Persia
verseText: For Ezra had set his heart to study the Law of the LORD, and to do it and to teach his statutes and rules in Israel. (ESV)

text: What problem did Ezra discover among the people and officials in Judah upon his arrival?
verseText: After these things had been done, the officials approached me and said, 'The people of Israel and the priests and the Levites have not separated themselves from the peoples of the lands with their abominations... For they have taken some of their daughters to be wives for themselves and for their sons...' (ESV)

text: How did Ezra react when he heard about the intermarriages?
options: He tore his garments, pulled hair from his head and beard, and sat appalled
He wrote a letter to the king
verseText: As soon as I heard this, I tore my garment and my cloak and pulled hair from my head and beard and sat appalled. (ESV)

text: What did Ezra do publicly after learning about the sin of intermarriage?
options: He prayed and confessed the sins of the people
verseText: And at the evening sacrifice I rose from my fasting, with my garment and my cloak torn, and fell upon my knees and spread out my hands to the LORD my God, saying: 'O my God, I am ashamed and blush to lift my face to you, my God, for our iniquities have risen higher than our heads, and our guilt has mounted up to the heavens.' (ESV)

text: Who suggested the plan to make a covenant with God and put away the foreign wives and children?
verseText: And Shecaniah the son of Jehiel, of the sons of Elam, addressed Ezra: 'We have broken faith with our God and have married foreign women from the peoples of the land, but even now there is hope for Israel in spite of this. Therefore let us make a covenant with our God to put away all these wives and their children...' (ESV)

text: What action did the assembly of returned exiles agree to take regarding the foreign wives?
options: To send them back to Persia
verseText: Now then make confession to the LORD, the God of your fathers and do his will. Separate yourselves from the peoples of the land and from the foreign wives.' Then all the assembly answered with a loud voice, 'It is so; we must do as you have said.' (ESV)

text: What items did King Cyrus return to the Jews to be placed in the rebuilt Temple?
options: The gold and silver vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar
verseText: Cyrus the king also brought out the vessels of the house of the LORD that Nebuchadnezzar had carried away from Jerusalem and placed in the house of his gods. Cyrus king of Persia brought these out in charge of Mithredath the treasurer, who counted them out to Sheshbazzar the prince of Judah. (ESV)

text: What was the name of the High Priest who returned with Zerubbabel?
verseText: They came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Seraiah, Reelaiah, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispar, Bigvai, Rehum, Baanah. (ESV)

text: Where did the returning exiles first gather to rebuild the altar?
verseText: When the seventh month came, and the children of Israel were in the towns, the people gathered as one man to Jerusalem. (ESV)

text: What motivated the adversaries to hinder the Temple rebuilding?
options: Fear of the Jews' growing power and influence
verseText: Then the people of the land discouraged the people of Judah and made them afraid to build and bribed counselors against them to frustrate their purpose, all the days of Cyrus king of Persia, even until the reign of Darius king of Persia. (ESV)

text: What did the officials Tattenai and Shethar-bozenai do regarding the Temple rebuilding?
options: Questioned the Jews' authority and wrote to King Darius
Actively tried to destroy the work
verseText: At the same time Tattenai the governor of the province Beyond the River and Shethar-bozenai and their associates came to them and spoke to them thus: 'Who gave you a decree to build this house and to finish this structure?' ... The copy of the letter that Tattenai the governor of the province Beyond the River and Shethar-bozenai and his associates... sent to Darius the king. (ESV)

text: What was found in the archives at Ecbatana?
options: The scroll with Cyrus's original decree
verseText: And in Ecbatana, the citadel that is in the province of Media, a scroll was found on which this was written: 'A record.' (ESV)

text: What did King Darius decree should happen to anyone who altered his order supporting the Temple rebuilding?
options: A beam pulled from his house, impaled on it, and house made a dunghill
verseText: Also I make a decree that if anyone alters this edict, a beam shall be pulled out of his house, and he shall be impaled on it, and his house shall be made a dunghill. (ESV)

text: Ezra was a descendant of which important biblical figure?
verseText: Ezra the son of Seraiah, son of Azariah, son of Hilkiah... son of Zadok, son of Ahitub... son of Phinehas, son of Eleazar, son of Aaron the chief priest. (ESV)

text: What did Ezra and his group do before starting their journey from Babylonia to Jerusalem?
options: Proclaimed a fast to seek God's protection
verseText: Then I proclaimed a fast there, at the river Ahava, that we might humble ourselves before our God, to seek from him a safe journey for ourselves, our children, and all our goods. (ESV)

text: Why was Ezra ashamed to ask the king for soldiers and horsemen?
options: He had told the king God would protect them
verseText: For I was ashamed to ask the king for a band of soldiers and horsemen to protect us against the enemy on our way, since we had told the king, 'The hand of our God is for good on all who seek him, and the power of his wrath is against all who forsake him.' (ESV)

text: What did the people do while Ezra prayed and confessed?
verseText: While Ezra prayed and made confession, weeping and casting himself down before the house of God, a very great assembly of men, women, and children, gathered to him out of Israel, for the people wept bitterly. (ESV)

text: How long did it take for the officials to investigate the cases of intermarriage?
verseText: Then the returned exiles did so. Ezra the priest selected men, heads of fathers' houses, according to their fathers' houses, each of them designated by name. On the first day of the tenth month they sat down to examine the cases; and they finished dealing with all the men who had married foreign women by the first day of the first month. (ESV)

text: What specific phrase indicates the fulfillment of prophecy in Cyrus's decree?
options: 'that the word of the LORD by the mouth of Jeremiah might be fulfilled'
'as it is written in the Law of Moses'
'according to the command of the God of Israel'
'in the first year of his reign'
verseText: In the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, that the word of the LORD by the mouth of Jeremiah might be fulfilled, the LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia... (ESV)

text: Who is referred to as 'Sheshbazzar the prince of Judah' and likely identified with Zerubbabel?
options: The one who received the Temple vessels from Cyrus
verseText: Cyrus king of Persia brought these out in charge of Mithredath the treasurer, who counted them out to Sheshbazzar the prince of Judah. (ESV)

text: Approximately how many people returned in the first wave of exiles led by Zerubbabel?
verseText: The whole assembly together was 42,360, besides their male and female servants, of whom there were 7,337, and they had 200 male and female singers. (ESV)

text: Why did the returning exiles build the altar first, even before the Temple foundation?
options: To resume sacrifices and seek God's favor and protection
It was the easiest part to build
They needed a place to cook food
verseText: They set the altar in its place, for fear was on them because of the peoples of the lands, and they offered burnt offerings on it to the LORD, burnt offerings morning and evening. (ESV)

text: What feast did the people celebrate immediately after rebuilding the altar?
verseText: And they kept the Feast of Booths, as it is written, and offered the daily burnt offerings by number according to the rule, as each day required, (ESV)

text: Why did the older generation weep when the Temple foundation was laid?
options: The new Temple seemed insignificant compared to Solomon's Temple
They were sad to be back in Jerusalem
verseText: But many of the priests and Levites and heads of fathers' houses, old men who had seen the first house, wept with a loud voice when they saw the foundation of this house being laid... (ESV)

text: What was the specific accusation made against the Jews in the letter to King Artaxerxes (likely a different Artaxerxes or an interpolation)?
options: That Jerusalem was a rebellious city, harmful to kings
That they were refusing to pay taxes
That they were building fortifications without permission
That they were worshipping other gods
verseText: ...the Jews who came up from you to us have gone to Jerusalem. They are rebuilding that rebellious and wicked city... be it known to the king that if this city is rebuilt and the walls finished, they will not pay tribute, custom, or toll, and the royal revenue will be impaired. (ESV)

text: Which kings' reigns saw the opposition that halted the Temple work?
verseText: ...all the days of Cyrus king of Persia, even until the reign of Darius king of Persia. And in the reign of Ahasuerus, in the beginning of his reign, they wrote an accusation... In the days of Artaxerxes... Then the work on the house of God that is in Jerusalem stopped, and it ceased until the second year of the reign of Darius king of Persia. (ESV)

text: What argument did the Jewish elders use when questioned by Tattenai?
options: They cited Cyrus's original decree permitting the rebuilding
They stated they were Persian citizens
verseText: And this was their reply to us: 'We are the servants of the God of heaven and earth, and we are rebuilding the house that was built many years ago, which a great king of Israel built and finished... However, in the first year of Cyrus king of Babylon, Cyrus the king made a decree that this house of God should be rebuilt.' (ESV)

text: What specific instructions did Darius give Tattenai regarding the Temple rebuilding?
options: Do not interfere, provide resources, punish obstructors
verseText: 'Therefore, you, Tattenai, governor of the province Beyond the River, Shethar-bozenai, and your associates... keep away; let the work on this house of God alone... The cost is to be paid to these men in full and without delay... Also I make a decree that if anyone alters this edict, a beam shall be pulled out of his house...' (ESV)

text: What types of sacrifices were offered at the dedication of the second Temple?
options: Bulls, rams, lambs, and male goats for a sin offering
verseText: They offered at the dedication of this house of God 100 bulls, 200 rams, 400 lambs, and as a sin offering for all Israel 12 male goats, according to the number of the tribes of Israel. (ESV)

text: What authority did the letter from King Artaxerxes grant Ezra?
options: To teach the Law, appoint magistrates/judges, use royal funds, punish lawbreakers
To command the Persian army in the region
verseText: 'And you, Ezra, according to the wisdom of your God that is in your hand, appoint magistrates and judges who may judge all the people in the province Beyond the River... Whoever will not obey the law of your God and the law of the king, let judgment be strictly executed on him, whether for death or for banishment or for confiscation of goods or for imprisonment.' (ESV)

text: Besides priests and Levites, what other Temple personnel returned with Ezra?
verseText: And there went up also to Jerusalem, in the seventh year of Artaxerxes the king, some of the people of Israel, and some of the priests and Levites, the singers and gatekeepers, and the temple servants... no tribute, custom, or toll may be imposed on any of the priests, the Levites, the singers, the doorkeepers, the temple servants, or other servants of this house of God. (ESV)

text: Why did Ezra specifically seek Levites to join his group before departing?
options: He found no Levites among those initially gathered, and they were needed for Temple service
verseText: I gathered them to the river that runs to Ahava, and there we camped three days. As I reviewed the people and the priests, I found there none of the sons of Levi. (ESV)

text: Who was entrusted with the gold, silver, and vessels during the journey to Jerusalem?
options: A select group of priests and Levites
verseText: Then I set apart twelve of the leading priests: Sherebiah, Hashabiah, and ten of their kinsmen with them... So the priests and the Levites took over the weight of the silver and the gold and the vessels, to bring them to Jerusalem, to the house of our God. (ESV)

text: What theological reason did Ezra give in his prayer for why the people's intermarriage was so serious?
options: It violated God's command to remain separate from pagan nations and risked assimilation
It broke the covenant made at Sinai
verseText: ...which you commanded by your servants the prophets, saying, 'The land that you are entering, to take possession of it, is a land impure with the impurity of the peoples of the lands... Therefore do not give your daughters to their sons, neither take their daughters for your sons...' (ESV)

text: What specific consequence did Ezra fear God might bring because of the intermarriages?
options: Complete destruction, leaving no remnant or survivor
verseText: ...shall we again break your commandments and intermarry with the peoples who practice these abominations? Would you not be angry with us until you consumed us, so that there should be no remnant or survivor? (ESV)

text: What was the penalty proposed for those who refused to assemble in Jerusalem to address the intermarriage issue?
options: Forfeiture of property and exclusion from the assembly
verseText: ...if anyone did not come within three days, by order of the officials and the elders all his property should be forfeited, and he himself banned from the congregation of the exiles. (ESV)

text: Why did the people request that the investigation into intermarriages be handled by officials over time, rather than immediately by the whole assembly?
options: Large number of cases, rainy season, people lived far away
They wanted to delay the process
verseText: But the people are many, and it is a time of heavy rain; we cannot stand in the open. Nor is this a task for one day or for two, for we have greatly transgressed in this matter. Let our officials stand for the whole assembly... (ESV)

text: Which groups were specifically mentioned as having taken foreign wives?
verseText: Among the sons of the priests who had married foreign women were found... Of the Levites... And of Israel... (ESV)

text: What offering did the priests who had married foreign women make as a guilt offering?
verseText: They pledged themselves to put away their wives, and their guilt offering was a ram of the flock for their guilt. (ESV)

text: The book of Ezra primarily covers which two distinct periods/returns?
options: The return under Zerubbabel and the return under Ezra
The rebuilding of the altar and the rebuilding of the walls
The reign of Cyrus and the reign of Darius
verseText: (Structure of the book: Chapters 1-6 focus on the first return and Temple rebuilding (~538-515 BC). Chapters 7-10 focus on Ezra's return and reforms (~458 BC).)

text: What is the significance of listing the families and numbers of the first returnees in Ezra chapter 2?
options: To establish their identity as the legitimate remnant of Israel
verseText: (The detailed list authenticates the lineage and claims of those returning from Babylon, emphasizing continuity with pre-exilic Israel.)

text: The letter written by the adversaries in Ezra 4 mixes events from different periods. What does this suggest about the compiler's purpose?
options: To thematically group instances of opposition, showing its persistent nature
verseText: (Chapter 4 groups different opposition accounts, including later ones related to wall rebuilding under Xerxes/Artaxerxes, to highlight the ongoing struggle faced by the returnees, even though it disrupts the Temple narrative's strict chronology.)

text: What does the term 'Beyond the River' (or 'Trans-Euphrates') refer to?
options: The Persian administrative province west of the Euphrates River, including Judah
The land east of the Jordan River
verseText: ...and the rest of the nations whom the great and noble Osnappar deported and settled in the cities of Samaria and in the rest of the province Beyond the River... At the same time Tattenai the governor of the province Beyond the River... (ESV)

text: What role did the 'eye of their God' play when Tattenai questioned the elders?
options: It protected the elders so the work was not stopped pending Darius's reply
It caused the Temple to shine
verseText: But the eye of their God was on the elders of the Jews, and they did not stop them until a report should reach Darius and then an answer be returned by letter concerning it. (ESV)

text: King Artaxerxes' letter refers to Ezra being skilled in the 'Law of your God' and the 'law of the king'. What does this imply?
options: Persian administration recognized and respected Jewish Law for internal matters
Ezra was also a Persian official
Jewish Law was incorporated into Persian law
verseText: Whoever will not obey the law of your God and the law of the king, let judgment be strictly executed on him... (ESV)

text: What was the significance of the river Ahava?
options: It was the gathering point for Ezra's group before departing Babylonia
verseText: I gathered them to the river that runs to Ahava... Then I proclaimed a fast there, at the river Ahava... Then we departed from the river Ahava on the twelfth day of the first month, to go to Jerusalem. (ESV)

text: Ezra's prayer in chapter 9 recounts Israel's history of sin. What is the purpose of this historical review?
options: To emphasize the recurring pattern of disobedience and God's grace, contextualizing the current sin
To impress the listeners with his knowledge
verseText: (Ezra connects the present sin of intermarriage to Israel's past failures, highlighting the danger of repeating history and provoking God's judgment again, despite His recent mercy in allowing the return.)

text: The covenant made in Ezra 10 involved separating from foreign wives AND their children. Why were the children included?
options: To ensure a complete break from foreign religious/cultural influence
The children were also considered foreign
verseText: Therefore let us make a covenant with our God to put away all these wives and their children, according to the counsel of my lord and of those who tremble at the commandment of our God... (ESV)

text: How does the end of Ezra, listing names of offenders, serve as a conclusion?
options: It demonstrates the seriousness of the sin and the extent of the required repentance
It shows the failure of Ezra's mission
verseText: (The list underscores the widespread nature of the transgression, affecting even priests and Levites, and documents the community's commitment, however painful, to address the sin.)

text: What was the relationship between Zerubbabel and Jeshua?
options: Zerubbabel was the political leader (governor), Jeshua was the religious leader (High Priest)
verseText: Then arose Jeshua the son of Jozadak, with his fellow priests, and Zerubbabel the son of Shealtiel with his kinsmen, and they built the altar... (ESV) (cf. Haggai 1:1)

text: The 'Nethinim' or 'temple servants' who returned were likely descendants of whom?
options: Non-Israelites dedicated to Temple service in earlier times (e.g., Gibeonites)
verseText: The temple servants: the sons of Ziha, the sons of Hasupha, the sons of Tabbaoth... and 220 of the temple servants, whom David and his officials had set apart to attend the Levites... (ESV) (cf. Joshua 9:27)

text: What does the mixed reaction (shouting and weeping) at the laying of the Temple foundation signify about the community?
options: A community grappling with memory, loss, and hope for the future
A deep division over the project
Joy for the young, despair for the old
verseText: (It reflects the complex emotions: joy at the new beginning, but also grief for the lost glory of the past, representing a community marked by both trauma and faith.)

text: The prophets Haggai and Zechariah played a crucial role. What was their primary message?
options: Prioritize rebuilding the Temple over personal concerns
verseText: Now the prophets, Haggai and Zechariah... prophesied to the Jews... (Haggai 1:4 'Is it a time for you yourselves to dwell in your paneled houses, while this house lies in ruins?') (Zechariah 1:16 '...My house shall be built in it...') (ESV)

text: Darius's decree mentions funding the Temple work from the 'royal revenue of the province Beyond the River'. What does this show about Persian policy?
options: Support for local cults to ensure stability and loyalty
verseText: Moreover, I make a decree regarding what you shall do for these elders of the Jews for the rebuilding of this house of God. The cost is to be paid to these men in full and without delay from the royal revenue, the tribute of the province Beyond the River... (ESV)

text: Ezra 7:10 states Ezra 'set his heart to study the Law... to do it and to teach it'. What does this three-fold description emphasize?
options: The integration of knowledge, practice, and instruction in Ezra's life and mission
verseText: For Ezra had set his heart to study the Law of the LORD, and to do it and to teach his statutes and rules in Israel. (ESV)

text: The list of peoples the Israelites were intermarrying with (Ezra 9:1) includes Canaanites, Hittites, etc. Why is this list significant?
options: These were the nations God explicitly forbade Israel from marrying due to their idolatry
They were the most powerful nations nearby
verseText: ...the officials approached me and said, 'The people of Israel... have not separated themselves from the peoples of the lands with their abominations, from the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, the Ammonites, the Moabites, the Egyptians, and the Amorites.' (ESV)

text: Shecaniah's statement 'even now there is hope for Israel' (Ezra 10:2) comes immediately after acknowledging great sin. What does this show?
options: The possibility of repentance and restoration even after serious failure
verseText: And Shecaniah the son of Jehiel... addressed Ezra: 'We have broken faith with our God and have married foreign women from the peoples of the land, but even now there is hope for Israel in spite of this.' (ESV)

text: The assembly agrees 'we must do as you have said' (Ezra 10:12). What does this collective response indicate?
options: The community's acceptance of Ezra's authority and the need for corporate repentance
verseText: Then all the assembly answered with a loud voice, 'It is so; we must do as you have said.' (ESV)

text: The Hebrew and Aramaic languages are both used in Ezra. Where does the main Aramaic section occur and what does it primarily cover?
options: Ezra 4:8-6:18; correspondence with Persian officials and decrees regarding the Temple
verseText: (The shift to Aramaic, the administrative language of the Persian Empire, occurs when quoting official letters and decrees exchanged between local officials, the Jews, and the Persian court concerning the Temple rebuilding. Another Aramaic section is Artaxerxes' letter in Ch 7.)

text: Ezra 2 and Nehemiah 7 contain nearly identical lists of returnees. What might account for the minor variations between them?
options: Scribal updates, different times of census, or different purposes for the lists
One list refers to a different group
verseText: (Scholars suggest the lists represent slightly different stages or methods of counting, potential scribal copying differences over time, or reflect the specific administrative needs at the time each book was compiled.)

text: The identity of 'Ahasuerus' and 'Artaxerxes' in Ezra 4:6-7 is debated. If they are Xerxes I and Artaxerxes I, what historical event does the opposition likely relate to?
options: The later attempt to rebuild Jerusalem's walls (described in Nehemiah), not the Temple
The initial Temple rebuilding under Cyrus
verseText: (If these kings are Xerxes and Artaxerxes I, the accusations about rebuilding the 'rebellious city' and its walls (v. 12) fit better with the opposition Nehemiah faced decades after the Temple was completed, suggesting Ezra 4 groups opposition thematically rather than strictly chronologically.)

text: What is the significance of the Temple vessels being counted and returned (Ezra 1:9-11)?
options: Symbolizes restoration of true worship, continuity with the past, and fulfillment of God's promise
verseText: (The return of the sacred vessels, originally taken by Nebuchadnezzar, signifies the reversal of judgment, the legitimacy of the second Temple, and Cyrus's role in God's plan.)

text: The phrase 'stirred up the spirit of Cyrus' (Ezra 1:1) emphasizes what theological concept?
options: God's sovereignty over world rulers and historical events
verseText: In the first year of Cyrus king of Persia... the LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia... (ESV) (This highlights that even the actions of pagan kings are part of God's sovereign plan to fulfill His purposes.)

text: Why might the adversaries have initially offered to help rebuild the Temple (Ezra 4:2)?
options: To infiltrate and control the project, or to syncretize worship
verseText: ...they approached Zerubbabel... and said to them, 'Let us build with you, for we worship your God as you do, and we have been sacrificing to him ever since the days of Esarhaddon king of Assyria who brought us here.' (ESV) (Their claim suggests a syncretistic worship, unacceptable to Zerubbabel, implying their motive was likely control or dilution of pure Yahwism.)

text: Zerubbabel's rejection of the adversaries' help (Ezra 4:3) is based on what principle?
options: Maintaining religious purity and exclusive commission from Cyrus/God
verseText: But Zerubbabel, Jeshua, and the rest of the heads of fathers' houses in Israel said to them, 'You have nothing to do with us in building a house to our God; but we alone will build to the LORD, the God of Israel, as King Cyrus the king of Persia has commanded us.' (ESV)

text: The search for Cyrus's decree was conducted first in Babylon, then found in Ecbatana (Ezra 6:1-2). What might this imply?
options: The vastness and complexity of Persian bureaucracy; decrees stored in multiple locations
Darius was reluctant to find it
verseText: Then Darius the king made a decree, and search was made in Babylonia, in the house of the archives... And in Ecbatana, the citadel that is in the province of Media, a scroll was found... (ESV) (Ecbatana was a summer capital, suggesting records were kept in various administrative centers.)

text: Darius refers to the Temple as the place 'where they offer pleasing sacrifices to the God of heaven and pray for the life of the king and his sons' (Ezra 6:10). What does this reveal about Persian imperial ideology?
options: Belief that supporting local cults brought divine blessings upon the empire and ruler
verseText: ...that they may offer pleasing sacrifices to the God of heaven and pray for the life of the king and his sons. (ESV) (This reflects a common ancient Near Eastern practice where rulers supported local deities expecting blessings and stability in return.)

text: The reference to the 'king of Assyria' helping them in Ezra 6:22 is surprising, as Darius was Persian. What is a likely explanation?
options: 'King of Assyria' used as a title for the current Mesopotamian power holder (Persia inheriting the domain)
A scribal error for 'King of Persia'
A reference to God turning the heart of their former oppressors
A quote from an older source
verseText: ...for the LORD had made them joyful and had turned the heart of the king of Assyria to them, so that he aided them in the work of the house of God, the God of Israel. (ESV) (Persian kings inherited titles of previous empires ruling the region; it emphasizes God's power over the ruling empire.)

text: Ezra's lineage (Ezra 7:1-5) traces him back to Aaron. Why is establishing this priestly lineage important for his mission?
options: It validates his authority to handle sacred matters, interpret Law, and lead Temple-centered reforms
verseText: (As a descendant of Aaron, Ezra possessed the inherited religious authority necessary for the task of restoring proper worship and teaching the Law in Jerusalem.)

text: Artaxerxes' decree grants tax exemption to Temple personnel (Ezra 7:24). What was the likely political motivation for this?
options: To secure the loyalty and prayers of the influential priestly class
Lack of funds to pay them
verseText: We also notify you that it shall not be lawful to impose tribute, custom, or toll on any of the priests, the Levites, the singers, the doorkeepers, the temple servants, or other servants of this house of God. (ESV) (This was a common Persian strategy to gain favor with religious groups within the empire.)

text: Ezra waited at the river Ahava to gather Levites (Ezra 8:15). What does the initial lack of Levites in his group suggest?
options: Possible reluctance among Levites to leave Babylonia or undertake the difficult journey/task
verseText: As I reviewed the people and the priests, I found there none of the sons of Levi. (ESV) (This may reflect complex factors, including potentially better established lives in Babylon or apprehension about the situation in Judah.)

text: The detailed accounting of the treasures upon arrival in Jerusalem (Ezra 8:33-34) emphasizes what?
options: Faithfulness, accountability, and the successful completion of the mission under God's protection
verseText: On the fourth day the silver and the gold and the vessels were weighed out in the house of our God... The whole weight was recorded at that time. (ESV) (This careful process demonstrates integrity and acknowledges God's provision and protection during the journey.)

text: Ezra's prayer identifies the returned remnant as 'a peg in his holy place' (Ezra 9:8). What does this metaphor signify?
options: A small but secure foothold granted by God, ensuring survival and presence
verseText: But now for a brief moment favor has been shown by the LORD our God, to leave us a remnant and to give us a secure hold ('a peg') within his holy place... (ESV) (A tent peg provides stability; the metaphor suggests God has granted the remnant a firm, though perhaps small, place of security and belonging.)

text: Ezra includes himself in the confession ('our iniquities', 'our guilt') in Ezra 9. What does this demonstrate?
options: His identification with the community and corporate responsibility for sin
His personal guilt in the matter
verseText: 'O my God, I am ashamed and blush to lift my face to you, my God, for our iniquities have risen higher than our heads, and our guilt has mounted up to the heavens.' (ESV) (As a leader, Ezra fully identifies with the people's sin, even if not personally culpable in this specific instance.)

text: Shecaniah acknowledges Ezra's distress ('according to the counsel of my lord and of those who tremble at the commandment') in Ezra 10:3. What does 'tremble at the commandment' imply?
options: Deep reverence and fear of disobeying God's Law
verseText: Therefore let us make a covenant with our God to put away all these wives and their children, according to the counsel of my lord and of those who tremble at the commandment of our God... (ESV) (cf. Ezra 9:4, Isaiah 66:2) (It describes those who take God's word with utmost seriousness and awe.)

text: Who opposed the plan to separate from foreign wives, according to Ezra 10:15?
options: Jonathan son of Asahel and Jahzeiah son of Tikvah (supported by two Levites)
No one is mentioned as opposing
verseText: Only Jonathan the son of Asahel and Jahzeiah the son of Tikvah opposed this, and Meshullam and Shabbethai the Levite supported them. (ESV) (The exact nature of their opposition - whether to the plan itself or the procedure - is debated, but they are noted as dissenters.)

text: The book of Ezra ends somewhat abruptly after listing the offenders. What might be the theological or literary reason for this ending?
options: To emphasize that covenant faithfulness requires ongoing vigilance and action, leaving the story 'unfinished'
The scribe ran out of parchment
verseText: All these had married foreign women, and some of them had wives who had borne children. (ESV) (The stark ending highlights the difficult reality of repentance and the ongoing challenge of maintaining covenant purity, rather than providing a neat resolution.)

text: How does the theme of 'separation' function throughout the book of Ezra?
options: Separation from pagan practices/peoples is essential for covenant renewal and maintaining identity
Separation of powers between priest and governor
verseText: (From separating themselves to keep the Passover (6:21) to Ezra's horror at the lack of separation (9:1) and the final command to separate (10:11), the theme underscores the need for holiness and distinction from surrounding cultures.)

text: What is the relationship between the books of Ezra and Nehemiah in the Hebrew Bible?
options: They were originally considered a single book, Ezra-Nehemiah
Nehemiah is a commentary on Ezra
Ezra is a sequel to Nehemiah
verseText: (In the traditional Hebrew canon, Ezra and Nehemiah form one work, covering the restoration period under Persian rule.)

text: The rebuilding of the Temple in Ezra faces opposition similar to the rebuilding of the walls in Nehemiah. What recurring pattern does this reveal?
options: God's work often faces external opposition and internal challenges
verseText: (Both narratives highlight that efforts to restore covenant community and worship according to God's will inevitably encounter resistance from those who oppose God's purposes.)

text: Ezra's authority seems derived from both divine Law and Persian decree. How does the book portray the relationship between these two sources of authority?
options: Persian authority is shown as God's instrument to enable obedience to divine Law
verseText: (Ezra is skilled in God's Law (7:6, 10), and Artaxerxes empowers him to enforce both God's Law and the king's law (7:26), showing God working through the empire to restore His people.)

text: The sin of intermarriage is presented as a threat to the 'holy race' (Ezra 9:2). What is the primary concern behind this language?
options: Religious and covenantal identity, not ethnic purity in a modern sense
verseText: For they have taken some of their daughters to be wives for themselves and for their sons, so that the holy race has mixed itself with the peoples of the lands. (ESV) (The concern is the dilution of covenant faithfulness and the adoption of pagan practices through assimilation with surrounding peoples who worship other gods.)

text: Compare the leadership styles of Zerubbabel and Ezra.
options: Zerubbabel focuses on physical rebuilding (Temple), Ezra on spiritual/legal reform (Torah)
Zerubbabel was military, Ezra was political
verseText: (Zerubbabel (with Jeshua) leads the initial return and Temple construction project. Ezra, arriving later, focuses on teaching the Law and addressing the issue of intermarriage, representing a shift towards community definition based on Torah observance.)

text: What does the voluntary fasting and prayer before the journey (Ezra 8:21-23) reveal about the community's reliance?
options: Reliance on God for protection rather than human means (like a royal escort)
verseText: Then I proclaimed a fast... to seek from him a safe journey... For I was ashamed to ask the king for a band of soldiers... So we fasted and implored our God for this, and he listened to our entreaty. (ESV)

text: The decision to dissolve marriages in Ezra 10 is ethically challenging. How might the participants have understood its necessity within their context?
options: As a drastic but necessary measure to prevent covenantal annihilation and assimilation
As commanded directly by God through Ezra
As punishment for the foreign wives
verseText: (Within the post-exilic context, maintaining covenant identity distinct from surrounding paganism was seen as crucial for survival. The action, though harsh, was likely viewed as essential surgery to save the community from religious compromise forbidden by the Law.)

text: How does the book of Ezra contribute to the understanding of post-exilic Jewish identity?
options: It emphasizes identity based on return from exile, Temple worship, and adherence to Torah
verseText: (Ezra highlights the formation of a community centered around the rebuilt Temple and, increasingly, the study and application of the Mosaic Law as interpreted by scribes like Ezra, shaping Judaism for centuries.)

text: The genealogy in Ezra 2 includes those who could not prove their Israelite descent (Ezra 2:59-62). What is the significance of including this detail?
options: Highlights the importance placed on lineage for participation in the restored community, especially priesthood
verseText: The following were those who came up from Tel-melah, Tel-harsha, Cherub, Addan, and Immer, though they could not prove their fathers' houses or their descent, whether they belonged to Israel... these sought their registration among those enrolled in the genealogies, but they were not found there, and so they were excluded from the priesthood as unclean. (ESV)

text: What is the potential connection between the prophecy of Jeremiah mentioned in Ezra 1:1 and the 70 years of exile?
options: Cyrus's decree is seen as the beginning of the fulfillment of Jeremiah's prophecy that the exile would last 70 years
verseText: In the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, that the word of the LORD by the mouth of Jeremiah might be fulfilled... (Jeremiah prophesied a 70-year period for Babylon's dominance/Judah's exile, after which God would restore His people.) (ESV)
